newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Suharto said well after health rumours hit market.
newsitem.headline: Suharto said well after health rumours hit market.

text.p: Rumours that President Suharto would undergo a medical check-up in Germany jolted Indonesia's financial markets again on Friday, even though sources in the presidential palace denied there were such plans.
"There is no such plan and there's no indication at all the president will have a new medical check-up," one source told Reuters by telephone.
"It's not true he will travel to Germany for a check-up," another palace source said.
The Indonesian rupiah was driven down to 2,406.5 against the dollar by the rumours, which dealers said came from Singapore traders, before settling at 2.404.8/05.8 by mid-morning.
Stock market trading was slow as most investors remained sidelined following the rumours. At 0519 GMT, the Jakarta composite index was off 0.32 percent at 639.58 points.
Suharto, 75, went to Germany for a medical check-up last year and was declared healthy for the man of his age.
Indonesian stock and foreign exchanges markets were roiled by fears over the health of the president, who has yet to publicly announce a successor.

Witneses said Suharto appeared healthy on Friday as he fulfilled his official duties during the day. These included a meetings with the secretary-general of China's state council and participants at a high-ranking meeting of armed forces' officials at the state Merdeka Palace.
The witnesses said Suharto, leader of the world's most populous Moslem nation, then attended Friday prayers with the military officers at a mosque in the palace grounds.
Several Jakarta-based newspapers carried stories and pictures of Suharto on Friday. They denied rumours that he had been ill on Thursday and confirmed he had carried out his normal office duties.
Palace sources said late on Thursday that Suharto was at home and in good health after a normal day's activities, despite rumours on foreign exchange markets that he was ill.
"These rumours are crazy. The president is at home and in good health," one source said.
Suharto's advancing age is unlikely to affect his nomination for a seventh, five-year term in office next year, political and diplomatic analysts said on Wednesday.

Senior diplomatic sources said there was no indication that Suharto, whose 30-year rule has brought stability and economic growth to the sprawling archipelago of 200 million people, intended to step aside, saying he was still very much in control.
